feed.title: NewsTracker: baltimore
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Right call? Orioles take the field in riot-torn Baltimore
entry.summary: Chicago White Sox catcher Tyler Flowers sits in the dugout of an empty stadium before playing the Baltimore Orioles in a baseball game, Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Right Call? Orioles Take the Field in Riot-Torn Baltimore
entry.summary: The team didn't divert any police from doing their job around the city, but the people of Baltimore didn't get a chance to turn the page by watching the home team play at Camden Yards.

entry.title: Right call? Orioles take the field in riot-torn Baltimore
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE (AP) - With rubble and debris looming nearby, and tempers still smoldering in riot-torn Baltimore, the Orioles played a baseball game on Wednesday.

In Baltimore, after a drug store was set on fire about four miles from the ballpark and the National Guard was summoned to restore order, they played a game because this was the only planned visit by this season by the Chicago White Sox.

entry.title: A look at the knowns and unknowns in the Baltimore case
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - A week and a half after 25-year-old Freddie Gray died, there are still many unanswered questions about the explosive case.

entry.title: A game with no fans: Should Orioles, White Sox have played?
entry.summary: Baltimore Orioles starting pitcher Ubaldo Jimenez throws to Chicago White Sox's Adam Eaton in the first inning of a baseball game, Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Tensions ease in Baltimore as curfew lifts, schools reopen
entry.summary: Broken store windows remain as members of the Anne Arundel County Police stand guard at the intersection of North Avenue and Pennsylvania Avenue, Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Clinton: Baltimore shows justice system 'out of balance'
entry.summary: Pointing to a wave of violence in Baltimore, Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that the nation's criminal justice system has gotten "out of balance" and must be restored through steps such as the use of body cameras by every police department in the country.

entry.title: Clinton: Baltimore shows justice system 'out of balance'
entry.summary: Clinton spoke in the days after violence and protests have swept through the streets of Baltimore following the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who suffered a spinal-cord injury while in police custody.

entry.title: Schools reopen in Baltimore, streets quiet after curfew
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - Schools reopened across the city and tensions seemed to ease Wednesday after Baltimore made it through the first night of its curfew without the widespread violence many had feared.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet after curfew
entry.summary: Police advance through a cloud of tear gas as they enforce curfew, Tuesday, April 28, 2015, in Baltimore, a day after unrest that occurred following Freddie Gray's funeral.

entry.title: Baltimore curfew ends with streets quiet, nearly empty
entry.summary: In an interview broadcast Wednesday on "The Steve Harvey Morning Show," President Barack Obama said the Baltimore riots show that police departments need to build more trust in black communities.

entry.title: Baltimore riots force 2nd postponed game between Orioles, White Sox
entry.summary: After a pair of postponements caused by rioting in Baltimore, the Orioles and Chicago White Sox will play Wednesday at Camden Yards in what is believed to be the first game without fans in Major League Baseball's history.

entry.title: Latest on police-custody death: Curfew
entry.summary: At midnight Tuesday, Baltimore police arrested one man wearing a Wu-Tang Clan T-shirt for violating the 10 p.m. curfew near the scene of Tuesday night's demonstration.

entry.title: Baltimore calm after some trouble as curfew began
entry.summary: But the rioting also brought out a sense of civic pride and responsibility in many Baltimore residents, with hundreds of volunteers turning out to sweep the streets of glass and other debris with brooms and trash bags donated by hardware stores.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet under curfew
entry.summary: Volunteers clean a CVS pharmacy Tuesday, April 28, 2015, in Baltimore, in the aftermath of rioting following Monday's funeral for Freddie Gray, who died in police custody.

entry.title: Baltimore streets quiet under curfew
entry.summary: Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, left, speaks as Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts, centre, listens, during a news conference, in Baltimore, Tuesday, April 28, 2015.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet under curfew
entry.summary: But as part of the state of emergency, the governor extended the period to no later than 47 hours, according to a letter he sent Tuesday to Judge Barbara Baer Waxman, the administrative judge for the Baltimore District Court.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet under curfew
entry.summary:
The clash came after a day of high tension but relative peace in Baltimore, which was rocked by looting and widespread arson Monday in the city's worst outbreak of rioting since 1968.

Just before midnight Tuesday, Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts declared the curfew, which ends at 5 a.m., a success.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet under curfew
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - Baltimore streets previously rocked by riots were eerily quiet early Wednesday as residents obeyed an all-night curfew enforced by 3,000 police and National Guardsmen.

entry.title: Police say curfew in riot-hit Baltimore working
entry.summary: But he warned that incidents in recent months "raise troubling questions" about the policing of black communities in the United States.

entry.title: Police enforce curfew in Baltimore, disperse protesters
Police clash with Baltimore protesters for a second night
entry.summary: Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake waited hours to ask the governor to declare a state of emergency, and the governor hinted she should have come to him earlier.

entry.title: Riot-hit Baltimore, an American city divided by income and opportunity
entry.summary: By comparison, across the whole of the U.S., the top take in $9.30 for every dollar earned at the bottom.

entry.title: 'Mum of the year': Baltimore mother filmed hitting and berating her son during riots
entry.summary: "That's my only son and at the end of the day I don't want him to be a Freddie Gray," Graham said.

entry.title: Thousands of police descend on Baltimore to enforce curfew after riots
entry.summary: Schools were closed on Tuesday, but were scheduled to reopen on Wednesday.

entry.title: Riots in Baltimore the product of anger, deep dysfunction
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - Baltimore is crab cakes, the cobblestone walkways of Fells Point, a vintage baseball stadium, the retro weirdness of John Waters.

entry.title: Watch: National Guard Meets Calmer Crowds Tuesday in Baltimore
entry.summary: Make certain that you have these National Guard troops.

entry.title: The Wire creator David Simon condemns 'selfish' Baltimore rioters
entry.summary: "If you can’t seek redress and demand reform without a brick in your hand, you risk losing this moment for all of us in Baltimore. Turn around. Go home. Please."

entry.title: Riots in Baltimore raise questions about police response
entry.summary: A man rides a bicycle through heavy smoke that is emitting from a nearby store on fire, Monday, April 27, 2015, during unrest following the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.

entry.title: Baltimore riot: Fires, chaos, National Guard after Freddie Gray funeral
entry.summary: The violence, which began in West Baltimore -- within a mile of where Freddie Gray was arrested and pushed into a police van earlier this month -- had by the end of the day spread to East Baltimore and neighborhoods close to downtown and near the baseball stadium.

entry.title: Baltimore mayor says outsiders turned peaceful protest violent
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (Reuters) - Baltimore's mayor and police on Sunday again blamed outside agitators for violence and vandalism that flared during a mostly peaceful protest over last week's death of a young black man who sustained an unexplained spinal injury while under arrest.

entry.title: Baltimore deploys Guard troops as riots erupt
entry.summary: Thousands of police and National Guard troopers were ordered to back up beleaguered officers in Baltimore on Tuesday after riots triggered by anger over the death of a black man in police custody.

entry.title: Baltimore racked by violence; governor calls out National Guard
entry.summary: Rioters in the streets of Baltimore are looting stores.

entry.title: Riots in Baltimore over man's death in police custody
entry.summary: A brick sits on a street as police standby, Monday, April 27, 2015, during a skirmish with demonstrators after the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.

entry.title: Riots in Baltimore over man's death in police custody
entry.summary:
Firefighters battle a blaze, Monday, April 27, 2015, after rioters plunged part of Baltimore into chaos, torching a pharmacy, setting police cars ablaze and throwing bricks at officers.

Residents watch as Baltimore police officers clash with protesters in the streets near Mondawmin Mall April 27, 2015 in Baltimore, Maryland.

A mourner embraces Gloria Darden, left, mother of Freddie Gray, before Gray's funeral, Monday, April 27, 2015, at New Shiloh Baptist Church in Baltimore.

entry.title: Riot, looting prompt state of emergency, curfew in Baltimore
entry.summary: Rep. Elijah Cummings, D-Md., addresses mourners at a funeral for Freddie Gray, Monday, April 27, 2015, at New Shiloh Baptist Church in Baltimore.

entry.title: AP PHOTOS: Riots Hit Baltimore After Freddie Gray Funeral
entry.summary: Rioting erupted in Baltimore on Monday evening, following the funeral of the black man who died in police custody after suffering a severe spinal cord injury.

entry.title: AP PHOTOS: Riots hit Baltimore after Freddie Gray funeral
entry.summary:
A demonstrator taunts police as they respond to thrown objects, Monday, April 27, 2015, after the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.

EDS NOTE: OBSCENE GESTURES - People stand on top of a Baltimore police car in Baltimore on Monday, April 27, 2015, during unrest following the funeral of Freddie Gray.

entry.title: Baltimore erupts in riots after funeral of man who died in police custody
entry.summary: The riots broke out just a few blocks from the funeral of Freddie Gray and then spread through much of West Baltimore in the most violent U.S. demonstrations since arson and shooting in Ferguson, Missouri, last year.

entry.title: Maryland governor declares state of emergency over Baltimore violence
entry.summary: April 27 (Reuters) - Maryland Governor Larry Hogan declared a state of emergency and activated the National Guard to address the violence in Baltimore, his office said on Monday.

entry.title: Baltimore erupts in riots after funeral of man who died in police custody [Photos]
entry.summary: Protesters hurled bricks, looted businesses and set fires in Baltimore on Monday in violence that injured at least seven police officers following the funeral of a 25-year-old black man who died after he was injured in police custody.

entry.title: Maryland governor declares state of emergency in Baltimore over rioting
entry.summary: A man carries items from a store as police vehicles burn after the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore on Monday.

entry.title: Obama pledges help for Baltimore riots after Gray funeral
entry.summary: WASHINGTON (AP) - President Barack Obama is pledging the federal government's help to respond to riots that have broken out in Baltimore following the funeral of Freddie Gray.

entry.title: Orioles' game in Baltimore postponed due to safety concerns (Yahoo Sports)
entry.summary: Rioters looted stores and threw rocks and bricks at Baltimore police about three miles from the stadium in the wake of the mysterious death of Gray.

entry.title: State of Emergency Declared Amid Violent Clashes in Baltimore
entry.summary: A man walks past a burning police vehicle, April 27, 2015, during unrest following the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.

entry.title: Riots erupt in Baltimore after Freddie Gray funeral
entry.summary: Baltimore police initially showed restraint on Monday but then began arresting people and prepared to use teargas and pepper spray.

entry.title: Baltimore clashes: violence flares after Freddie Gray's funeral
entry.summary:
Seven Baltimore police officers were injured on Monday as rioters threw bricks and stones and burned patrol cars in violent protests after the funeral of a black man who died in police custody.

The riots broke out just a few blocks from the site of the funeral of 25-year-old Freddie Gray in northwest Baltimore and then spread through other parts of the city, after local law enforcement warned of a threat by gangs.

Baltimore Police Captain Eric Kowalczyk said at a police briefing that one of the injured police officers was unresponsive and several had broken bones.

entry.title: US diplomat recalls racial tension in Baltimore
entry.summary:
A U.S. diplomat opened her speech on Iranian nuclear negotiations talking about how she grew up going to civil rights marches and says her father once helped baseball star Frank Robinson find a home in an all-white neighborhood of Baltimore.

The recent case of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who died after sustaining serious injuries while in the custody of Baltimore police, has intensified a national debate over police treatment of African-Americans.

entry.title: Barack Obama to send aide to Freddie Gray funeral in Baltimore on Monday
entry.summary: The White House says the head of President Barack Obama's initiative for minority males will attend the funeral of a Baltimore man who died after sustaining serious injuries while in police custody.

entry.title: Thousands expected to attend Freddie Gray's funeral in Baltimore - Dozens arrested as Freddie Gray protests turn violent in Baltimore - VIDEO: Cops: Gray wasn't buckled into seatbelt
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE - Thousands were expected Monday at a funeral for a man who died after sustaining serious spinal injuries while in the custody of Baltimore police.

Pastor Jamal Bryant, who was to deliver Gray's eulogy, said he expected Baltimore's New Shiloh Baptist Church to be filled for the service.

entry.title: Thousands expected to attend Freddie Gray's funeral in Baltimore - Dozens arrested as Freddie Gray protests turn violent in Baltimore - VIDEO: Cops: Gray wasn't buckled into seatbelt
entry.summary: Broderick Johnson, chairman of the My Brother's Keeper Task Force and a Baltimore native, is to be joined by two other administration officials, a White House statement said.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary:
The body of Freddie Gray lies inside his casket at Vaughn Greene Funeral Home, during his wake Sunday, April 26, 2015 in Baltimore.

Caira Byrd hold support signs for Freddie Gray outside of Vaughn Greene Funeral Home, during his wake in Baltimore, Md., Sunday, April 26, 2015.

A child accepts a gift of a bag of chips from a police officer outside the Western District before a march to City Hall for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015 in Baltimore.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary:
Fans fill the aisles in the ballpark after being told not to leave for their own safety during the Baltimore Orioles and the Boston Red Sox baseball game, Saturday, April 25, 2015, in Baltimore.

Fredricka Gray, center, the twin sister of Freddie Gray, speaks during a media availability at City Hall, after violence occurred after a march for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015 in Baltimore.

A protestor reacts after breaking a restaurant window after a rally for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary:
A night of violence gave way to a day of mourning Sunday for a man who died after sustaining serious injuries while in the custody of Baltimore police.

Police line a street in downtown Baltimore in response to protests that followed a rally for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015.

Police stand in helmets near Pratt Street after a march to City Hall for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015 in Baltimore.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary: Some 34 people were arrested, according to Baltimore Police Department, and six police officers sustained minor injuries.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary: Gray was arrested one week before that when officers chased him through a West Baltimore neighborhood and dragged him into a police van.

entry.title: The Latest: Photographer says police beat him during protest
entry.summary: The women said they knew Baltimore had issues with police before Gray's death.

entry.title: Photographer Says Baltimore Police Beat Him During Protest
entry.summary: J.M. Giordano, who works at the City Paper, says Baltimore police "swarmed over" him and hit him repeatedly.

entry.title: Photographer says Baltimore police beat him during protest
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - A photo editor for a Baltimore newspaper says he was beaten by police at a protest over the death of Freddie Gray.

entry.title: Former Baltimore Raven Ray Lewis sues attorney over failed MVP Lanes development project
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE - Former Baltimore Ravens star Ray Lewis is suing his former attorney over a failed development project he says cost him $1.5 million.

The suit accuses the Baltimore lawyer of convincing Lewis to sign a $1.5 million line of credit for the project, and later asking for another $200,000.

entry.title: Amazon.com introduces one-hour delivery to Baltimore, Miami
entry.summary: In Miami and Baltimore, Prime Now is available from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m., seven days a week.

entry.title: Amazon.com introduces one-hour delivery to Baltimore, Miami
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - Amazon.com is expanding its one-hour delivery Prime Now service to Baltimore and Miami.

The company says that the service will be expanded only to certain zip codes within Baltimore and Miami at first, but it plans to further expand within each city soon.

entry.title: Baltimore Ravens RB Pierce charged with drunken driving
entry.summary: Drafted in the third round of the 2002 draft out of Temple, Pierce started three games in three years with Baltimore.

entry.title: Baltimore Ravens running back Bernard Pierce charged with drunken driving
entry.summary: He was released by Baltimore as soon as the investigation began.

entry.title: Baltimore Ravens RB Pierce charged with drunken driving
entry.summary:
This undated handout provided by the Baltimore County Police Department shows Bernard Pierce.

Police in Maryland say Baltimore Ravens running back Bernard Pierce has been charged with drunken driving.

Baltimore County police say an officer stopped a Ford Mustang that was speeding around 2 a.m. Wednesday, March 18, 2015, in Towson, north of Baltimore.

entry.title: Three stabbed at Baltimore's Morgan State University: Report
entry.summary: Three football players at Baltimore's Morgan State University were stabbed on campus on Tuesday and one was seriously injured, the Baltimore Sun reported.

entry.title: Baltimore police say at least 3 stabbed on Morgan State University campus; 1 seriously hurt
entry.summary: It was the third instance of violence on the Baltimore campus in less than a week.

entry.title: Baltimore police say at least 3 people stabbed on Morgan State University campus in Maryland
Police: 1 Stabbed at Morgan State University in Maryland
entry.summary: Baltimore police say one person was stabbed and seriously injured at Morgan State University in Baltimore.

entry.title: High court to hear appeal from Baltimore police officer
Ray Rice Apologizes to Baltimore for 'Horrible Mistake'
entry.summary:
The last seven years that my family and I have spent in Baltimore have by far been the best of our lives.

Thank you, Baltimore Ravens, for all you have done for my family and I.

I love you all very much, and I'll always be proud to say I played for the Baltimore Ravens.
